title: Market overview: FTSE drops amid China and mining sector fears
text:
500.43 +2.13 
LONDON (ShareCast) - (ShareCast News) - 1630 (close): The FTSE ended down 0.83% to 5,909.24 points as woes about China's slowdown and the weakness in commodities persisted despite a rebound in mining stocks. Glencore (Xetra: A1JAGV - news ) reversed Monday's steep decline along with other mining stocks, but this failed to soothe concerns about the sector. The company's shares took a hit after Investec (LSE: INVP.L - news ) highlighted there was little equity value for shareholders and that commodity prices were in trouble. "For now, it seems that the rush for the exit has stopped in Glencore, but it is too early to say that a bottom has been reached, especially with the week's China data still to come," said IG (LSE: IGG.L - news ) analyst Chris Beauchamp. 
1500: US consumer confidence rose unexpectedly in September, figures show. The index monitoring sentiment among US consumers rose to 103.0 in September, up from 101.3 in the previous month and comfortably above analysts' expectations for a 97.3 reading. 
1356: Glencore remains "operationally and financially robust" and continues to retain strong lines of credit and secure access to funding. The company continues to be confident of its commodities' medium and long-term fundamentals. On Tuesday analysts at SP Angel made a similar point, telling clients that: "It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is unlikely that banks will pull their credit lines with Glencore easily - if they do we could have a "Lehman's moment" which will have much broader repercussions outside the sector. Sudden falls like this are worrying but the sky has yet to fall in on our heads." 1235: Glencore held secret talks on Tuesday morning with the most influential investor trade body in the City, the Investment Association, amid anger over its recent 'cash call' - particularly the absence of any prior consultation with them. 
1210: Goldman Sachs (NYSE: GS-PB - news ) has cut its year-end 2015 target for the benchmark S&P 500 to 2,000 points from 2,100 previously. 
1100: The CBI's distributive trades survey total sales index for September jumped to a reading of 49 from 24 in the month before (consensus: 28). 
0900: Plumbers' merchant Wolseley (LSE: WOS.L - news ) is lower after the firm warned of challenging markets outside the US and despite announcing a Â£300m share buyback. 
0835: Stocks have started lower on the back of follow-through selling from the Asian session and on Wall Street overnight. Stock is Glencore bouncing back, recovering roughly a third of its value on the back of positive commentary out of the likes of Citi and Bernstein. Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) of US-facing Wolseley on the other hand are getting hammered in the early going. Eurozone manufacturing PMIs and August data on consumer credit and mortgage approval numbers in the Uk are due out over the next hour. FTSE 100 down 27.39 points to 5,920.45.
